instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used on estimating the water content of leaves from Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaiso, Chile?
Output: Machine learning algorithms were used for classification and reconstruction procedures based on the spectral signature data collected from the leaves of Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaíso, Chile. Specifically, Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR) and Random Forest Regression (RFR) algorithms were utilized to reconstruct the leaf reflectance in the SWIR region, with the KRR-particular algorithm achieving the best reconstruction results with an RMSE less than 3%. Additionally, sixteen spectral indices were computed from the reconstructed reflectance data, with seven of them showing a relative percentage error less than 10%.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the estimation of the water content of leaves from Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaiso, Chile, and how far can this metric go in assessing the results of estimating the water content of leaves?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the estimation in the related study was the root mean square error (RMSE). The RMSE measures the average difference between the estimated reflectance values and the actual reflectance values of the leaves. In this case, the RMSE was found to be less than 9% in the spectrum estimation and 10% in spectral indices related to water content estimation.

The RMSE provides a quantitative measure of the overall accuracy of the estimation. It indicates the average magnitude of the errors in the estimation, with lower values indicating better accuracy.

instruction: How were the machine-learning regressors trained to estimate the water content of leaves from Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaiso, Chile, without knowledge of their spectrum in the short wave infra-red (SWIR) band?
Output: The machine-learning regressors were trained using a data set that consisted of the reflectance of 90 leaves per species at five dehydration stages. The reflectance measurements were taken between 350 nm and 2500 nm, covering the full spectrum. Two machine-learning regressors were trained with 70% of the data set to determine the unknown reflectance in the range of 1000 nm to 2500 nm. The remaining 30% of the data set was used for validation purposes. The results of the validation showed that the machine-learning regressors achieved a root mean square error of less than 9% in the spectrum estimation and an error of 10% in spectral indices related to water content estimation.

instruction: Can the achieved accuracy in estimating the water content of leaves using machine-learning regressors and reflectance data be considered superior to traditional methods in this study on Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaiso, Chile, without knowledge of their spectrum in the short wave infra-red (SWIR) band?
Output: Yes, the achieved accuracy in estimating the water content of leaves using machine-learning regressors and reflectance data can be considered superior to traditional methods in this study on Pinus radiata and Eucalyptus globulus species in Valparaiso, Chile, without knowledge of their spectrum in the short wave infra-red (SWIR) band.
